div.head: A few particulars of the late happily departed Widow Sister Eliz. Barker — Born at Tong in the year 1720 July 9th.

div.ab: Written in the side margins on the leftRead into the Congregation April 18th 1755 partook first time of the H Cong.What is the "H Cong"? Sept. 6th. same year

She was awakened to a knowledge of her lost condition soon after the Brethren came into Yorkshire. The sight of her lost con The distress of soul which she was in at this previous to her sight peace and happiness in our Savr. of her was so great as almost to bereif sp. “bereft” her of her senses, and over- come every other consideration. Hearing that there would be a preaching, here on the place, she she run with a little child in her arms (her daughter Hanah who now lives in the Sister House here) and when she got to Fulneck, she left the child in the care of a Family, best in returning home, her mind occupied with what she had heard, and the state of her own soul, that she forgot her child, and returned home without. Her neighbor believed and said, that the Inghamites (as the Brethren at that time were called) had thrown her mad.

When it pleased our Saviour to h reveal himself to her distressed heart, granting her pardon and peace, her joy and and gladness was as great as her as her sorrow and distress had been before. Her resolution now to live to him and his his people, brought upon her the several trial, from the enemies of the Brethren, who at that time were very numerous and exceeding bitter. The Landlord under whom they lived sent for her husband and insisted upon him it, that he & his wife should go to the Church, and not attendthat at that baudy sp. “bawdy” house — meaning the Brethren preaching place — threatening them at the same time, that if they did not obey him he would immediately turn them him off his work & out of their house. Her husband came home greatly alarmed, at the threats of his Landlord; and thinking that they would be ruined in their out ward circum stances if they, by ( attending the

meetings of the Brethren, — should provoke him to put his threatening into exe cution, endeavoured to persuade his our late Sister to leave the Brethren and go with him to Church. This she could not consent, upon which her husband grew exasperated at her he would and the told her that if determined to persist in following the Brethren he would be a ruined man — he would therefore leave her to her self and have nothing more to do with her, and left the house, and went and joined his old companions at the ail sp. “ale” house, who were glad to glad to have him in their company again, and that he had forsaken the Brethren and returned to his former course. They did all they could to further prejudice his mind of like more against the Brethren by saying all manner of evil against them

and encouraged him not to return to his wife but to forsake her intirely sp. “entirely” if she would not give up her connex ion sp. “connection” with the Brethren. In this way they spent 3 or 4 days, drinking the whole time. O our late Sister was left with 2 small children the oldest not above 2 years old. This Landlord got to hear that she refused persisted in going to the Brethren Meeting, at which he was terrible sicenraged, curses to gave her notice to quit the house immediately or he would pull it down upon her head, but as she did not obey, he came the next day with a company of workmen and with the in a most furious rage ordered the house to be uncover’d while she with her 2 small Children were in it when she saw that she must leave it she took her little ones, telling him as she passed Him, “He might might pull her earthly house down, but she had a house in heaven

which he could not destroy. Missing end quote " In these distressing circumstance she came for help and advice to the Brethren. who encouraged her to go and prevail, if possible, with her husband to return home with her. She did so, entreating him with many tears to leave that company and go with her, to which however he would not yield, excepting she would first promise him to go to the Church with him. She consented and accompanied him the next Sunday. But the night following he had a very alarming & long terrifying dream, respecting his conduct toward his wife and particularly his having forced her against her conscience to stay from the meeting of Fulneck and he likewise became very much destress’d about himself, promised never to hinder her and more and ever after he kept his promise. He himself soon after joined the Brethren's Congregation & partook of the H Comm with the same. Altho our late Sister now met with no obstacles in attending the preaching of the Brethren from the

the side of her husband, yet as several of her neighbors were, at that time, from mistaken notions of the Brethren. Were imbittered sp. “embittered” against them, she was the under the necessity of attending in secret & coming by ways for fear of being molested. She was for many years the general Nurse in Fulneck and was much Respected in that line. In the year 1778 she became a widow, and in 1783 she became got leave to be an a member Of this Congregation and moved into the Choir house; a favor which she often acknowledged with heartfelt thankfulness and gratitude to our gracious Lord. The Spiritual welfare of her Children was a concern which was ever uppermost in her mind, and whenever an opportunity Offered she never failed to warn those who were careless and indifferent about the salvation of their mortal souls, and to set before them the extreme danger of continuing living in

a carnal unregenerated course, and to set before them the love of Jesus to repenting sinners, and how happy they might be in him.
about 4 years ago she had the misfortune to get a fall and break her collar bone and was otherwise much hurt. Tho’ she so far recovered as to be able to walk about, yet she never got intirely sp. “entirely” well but all always complained of an in ward hurt in her side, previous to this she had enjoyed a good state of health and a strong constitution and a great flow of spirit.
